headline: South Africa’s unemployment rate hits new high -Report
summarized_story:
The unemployment rate in South Africa soared to its highest level on record in the final quarter of last year, official data showed Tuesday, as the impact of the pandemic continues to be felt.
The unemployment rate rose from 0.4 per cent to 35.3 per cent in the final three months of 2021, compared to 34.9 per cent in the previous quarter.
“This is the highest unemployment rate recorded since the start of the (quarterly labour force survey) in 2008,” StatsSA said in a report.
Compared to the 14.5 million South Africans with jobs, there are now about 7.9 million unemployed people in the continent’s most industrialised country.
The hardest COVID-hit African country has been diagnosed with more than 3.7 million infections, including 99,970 fatalities.

headline: Train attack: Family members apprehensive over whereabouts of commuters
summarized_story:

Mr Mohammed Barau, a resident of the Ungwan Rimi area of Kaduna, said he was at the train station to have an update regarding the incident, adding that his younger brother was in the train attack.
He said the staff of Kaduna State Emergency Management Agency and the Nigerian Red Cross, Kaduna chapter, conducted the evacuation.
Meanwhile, train service including other business activities at the Rigasa Railway station, Kaduna, has been grounded as a result of the incident.

The NNPC GMD argued that while Nigeria believes in the net zero drive and has already committed to it, it would continue to build on its gas infrastructure as a buffer before the achievement of the net zero target in 2060.
“First of all, let me put it in a general context, our country’s GDP contribution from the oil and gas is just nine per cent.
He explained that the energy poverty that Nigeria was confronted with, was also true of other African countries.
“The energy trilemma: energy access, affordability and sustainability should be taken in the holistic manner.
Oil and gas, according to our oil outlook, will continue to account for more than 45 per cent to 50 per cent of the global energy mix.

headline: Information Minister Lai Mohammed Blames Opposition PDP for Laying Foundation for Nigeria’s Misery
summarized_story:
Nigeria’s federal government has lambasted the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) for being the architect of the country’s economic hardship.
The government alleged that the mismanagement of national resources by the opposition party at a time the economy was buoyant laid the foundation for the current woes.
Minister of Information and Culture, Alhaji Lai Mohammed, made the accusation on Monday at a no-holds-barred press briefing in Abuja.
Mohammed stated further, “Gentlemen, there is nothing wrong in having a fiery and viable opposition in a democracy.
The main opposition party slammed Mohammed for provocatively claiming that Nigerians were better off under the APC.
